slidelink.displaytext: Prevention of Sexual Harassment at Workplace
Prevent Sexual Harassment as an Individual
Prevent Sexual Harassment as a Manager

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello, and welcome to the module on Prevention of Sexual Harassment at the Workplace.

My name is Neha, and I will be your guide for this course. Before we proceed, letâ€™s look at a few scenes.

What do they tell you?

Yes, they all depict instances of sexual harassment that may take place at work.

Sexual harassment takes place when someone faces unwelcomed acts or behaviours such as physical contact and advances, a demand or request for sexual favours, sexually-coloured remarks, or showing pornography. Any other misconduct or gesture that is sexual in nature can be construed as sexual harassment.

In this course, let us look at ways in which you can address sexual harassment at workplace.

By the end of this module, you will be able to:

·Define sexual harassment

·Identify different types of sexual harassment

·Identify what is not sexual harassment, and

·Explain the complaint process in case of sexual harassment.

Sexual harassment is not only about the most obvious or explicit misbehaviours like inappropriate touching or making suggestive comments. It is also about indirect or implied acts of misconduct connected to sexual harassment, to seek sexual favours. For example â€“ the promise of preferential treatment in employment, the threat of unfavourable treatment, a threat to present or future employment status, interference with work or creating an intimidating, offensive, or hostile work environment, and humiliating treatment likely to affect health or safety.

So, who all are governed under the Prevention of Sexual Harassment Act?

All employees of HDB Financial Services Ltd. are governed under the Prevention of Sexual Harassment Act.

All employees include Full Time Employees, Temporary Employees, Probationers, and Trainees.

Sexual harassment is defined by its impact on the victim and the work environment, and not the intention of the harasser.

Thus, if the recipient feels offended, humiliated, or intimidated by the conduct of the harasser, then it would be considered as sexual harassment.

Now that you are clear on what is sexual harassment, it is equally important for you to understand what is not sexual harassment. As long as the behaviour is mutual and friendly, it is not sexual harassment. For example, if a manager insists his team member to perform well and provides constructive feedback, or if a colleague offers a polite compliment, such actions do not fall under sexual harassment.

Letâ€™s look at some key definitions under the Sexual Harassment act.

Click each term to know more.

An aggrieved individual means a woman of any age, whether employed or not, who claims to have been facing sexual harassment at workplace.

A respondent is, usually the harasser, against whom the aggrieved individual has made a complaint.

Workplace includes all offices and branches of the Company.

It also includes any professional places visited by the employee with an employer or a colleague in the course of employment.
Let us look at a few examples to understand the definitions better. Click each image to follow a scenario.
Read the scenario carefully.
Read the second scenario carefully.

Identify the aggrieved person, respondent and workplace in this example.

Drag and drop each option to its appropriate placeholder and click Submit.

Can this act of Suraj be construed as sexual harassment?

Make your choice and click Submit.

Yes, thatâ€™s correct.

Dropping women employees when it is late considering their safety is not to be considered as the act of sexual harassment.

No, thatâ€™s incorrect.

Dropping women employees when it is late considering their safety is not to be considered as the act of sexual harassment.

What should Kiran do in such a case?

Make your choice and click Submit.

Yes, thatâ€™s correct. Kiran should immediately inform the HR about Sajjanâ€™s behaviour.

Oops, thatâ€™s incorrect. Kiran should immediately inform the HR about Sajjanâ€™s behaviour.

Here are few key takeaways from both the scenarios.

Remember that a conduct is NOT sexual harassment if it is welcomed.

Hence, it becomes all the more important to communicate a clear NO when faced with harassment.

Face the harasser and communicate firmly that the behaviour is not acceptable to you.

After saying a NO, if the behaviour still continues, take it up with the HR.

Put a complaint in writing, make immediate notes on the harassment and be specific in your details â€” note the time and place of each incident, what was said and done, and who witnessed the actions.

Now that you have a clear understanding of what is sexual harassment let us quickly look at the types of sexual harassment.

Sexual harassment can be divided into four types,

â€¢ Verbal

â€¢ Non-verbal

â€¢ Physical and

â€¢ Visual

Click each type to know about it.

Verbal harassment at work ranges from racist jokes to threats. It includes threatening, shouting, or insulting a colleague or an employee, graphic commentary about a personâ€™s physical attributes, use of profane or demeaning language, and using vulgar words.

Non-verbal sexual harassment can be acts of staring at someone, blowing kisses, winking, whistling or using printed materials that display sexually-oriented pictures or cartoons.

It can also mean updating sexually-oriented screen savers in office computers, or sending sexually-oriented notes, letters, faxes, emails or messages.

Physical harassment is any unwanted contact of a sexual nature. These include sexually suggestive or offensive touching or deliberate brushing against anotherâ€™s body. It also includes conduct against a person of a different gender in way that is assaulting, or blocking normal movement, or intentionally interfering with work.

Visual misconduct includes staring or the display of sexually suggestive or explicit posters. It can be photography, graffiti, drawings, gestures, inappropriate text messages or any objects that are sexually suggestive, like obscene notes, letters, email or internet information.
Having understood the four types of harassment, let us get to know why it is important to report an incident of sexual harassment.

It is necessary to stop unfair and unethical treatment. If left unreported, it could get worse. HDB is committed to creating a healthy working environment that enables employees to work without fear of prejudice, gender discrimination, and harassment. Even if you witness an act of Sexual Harassment, you must report it to HR. It is everyoneâ€™s responsibility to ensure a safe and harassment-free work environment. We believe that all employees have the right to be treated with fairness and dignity. Sexual harassment at the workplace is a grave offence and is punishable by law.

To prevent misconduct in the workplace, HDB Financial Services Ltd. follows POSH - Prevention of Sexual Harassment policy. As per the Act, reported cases of sexual harassment at the workplace will have to be resolved by an in-house committee within a period of 90 days. Letâ€™s find out more about this committee in detail.

To address complaints of sexual harassment, management of the company has constituted an Internal Committee, also called the IC. This committee derives its powers and functions from the POSH Act. The names and contact details of the members of the committee are published and displayed at a noticeable place in the premises as well as on the website of the company.

Click the pdf icon to know the Current members of the IC at HDB.

So how can the Internal committee resolve cases of sexual harassment for its employees?

There are four steps involved in this process:

â€¢Registering a complaint

â€¢Inquiry Process

â€¢Non-disclosure and

â€¢Post inquiry & disciplinary action

Letâ€™s take a look at each step in detail by taking the case of Isha, an aggrieved woman.

Before we proceed, let us look at Ishaâ€™s grievance.

Isha: Hello there, I am Isha. I work as an Operations Executive.

Isha: Nithin is one of my colleague who works as an Operations Manager and he is my good friend. Yogesh, a friend of Nithin, is also my colleague.

Isha: Yogesh started texting me on WhatsApp a few days ago. Since he was Nithinâ€™s friend, I didnâ€™t have a problem at first. But then he started addressing me as â€œbabesâ€ and began to make comments about my display picture.

Isha: Then he began forwarding vulgar jokes to me! Although I showed my discomfort to him, he did not stop. I even took this up with him face to face in the office.

Isha: What should I do now?

Narrator: Let us help Isha in addressing this issue.

Since Isha has sufficient reason to believe that she is sexually harassed, she must submit a written complaint of the incident to the committee within three months of the incident.

In cases where the aggrieved woman is unable to make a complaint due to physical incapacity, a complaint can be filed with the written consent of the aggrieved woman by her relative or friend, her co-worker, or an officer of the National Commission for Women or State Womenâ€™s Commission.

In cases where the aggrieved woman is unable to make a complaint on account of mental incapacity, a complaint can be filed by her relative or friend, a special educator, A qualified psychiatrist or psychologist, the guardian or person under whose authority she is receiving treatment or care, or any person who has knowledge of the incident.

Before initiating the inquiry, the committee may take steps to settle the matter between both the parties â€“ Isha and Yogesh, in this case, via a conciliatory process.

The conciliatory process is optional and non-monetary. In case there is no settlement arrived at, then the committee will begin with the inquiry process.

For this, Isha needs to submit written complaint to the committee with the names and addresses of the witnesses, i.e., Nithin.

On receipt of the complaint, the committee shall send one of the copies received from Isha to Nithin within seven days.

Nithin can also file his reply to the complaint along with his list of documents and names and addresses of witnesses within 10 ten working days from the date of the receipt of the complaint from the committee.

Click the PDF icon to know more about the process.

The IC would be entitled to elicit all forms of evidences for the inquiry, and the concerned parties will need to co-operate.

The identity and addresses of Isha, Yogesh and Nithin, or any other information relating to conciliation, enquiry, and proceedings, or recommendations of the committee, and the action taken by the employer, shall not be disclosed, published, communicated or made known to the press, public, or media in any manner.

Breach of confidentiality shall be treated as a misconduct which will be punishable as per the disclosure clause.

The next step is taking disciplinary action.

The Committee prepares and hands over the statement of the allegation to Yogesh within seven working days.

The respondent â€“ Yogesh, in this case, will get five working days to submit a written explanation, if he wants to, as a response against the allegations.

The IC will enquire into the matter within a month and invite both parties to present their views.

After the IC submits its findings, the company shall take appropriate disciplinary action against the guilty which may include termination, demotion, change of duty, etc.

In case the committee arrives at a conclusion that the allegation against the accused person, i.e. Yogesh, is false or malicious, it may recommend to take actions as per the Disciplinary Action Policy applicable to false evidence.

With this, we come to the end of the complaint redressal process.

Letâ€™s now look at another scenario.

Read the scenario carefully and make your choice.

Good Observation!

â€¢Neeta is not being harassed by Subhojit, so Subhojit cannot be punished.

â€¢The conversation was purely performance-based and non-threatening.

â€¢If Neeta files a complaint setting an inquiry on him, and the committee arrives at a conclusion that the allegation against Subhojit is false, it may recommend to take actions against Neeta as per the Disciplinary Action Policy applicable to false evidence.

Oops, thatâ€™s incorrect!

â€¢Neeta is not being harassed by Subhojit, so Subhojit cannot be punished.

â€¢The conversation was purely performance based and non-threatening.

â€¢If Neeta files a complaint setting an inquiry on him, and the committee arrives at a conclusion that the allegation against Subhojit is false, to take actions against Neeta as per the Disciplinary Action Policy applicable to false evidence.

Remember, as an individual, if you come across such an incident, you should speak up. Tell the respondent that the behaviour is unwelcomed, and ask him or her to stop. If the incident gets repeated, you should report the incident to the Committee or HR Manager. You may approach any of the committee members or the HR Manager informally for counsel.

As a Manager, if an employee approaches you with a complaint, you should guide employees to the proper procedures, report the matter to the committee immediately. In case the employee doesnâ€™t want to launch a formal complaint, please give the person a patient hearing. But do not resolve it informally and do not start an internal investigation under any circumstances. All investigations should be done only by the designated committee. When approached for counsel, avoid giving quick judgment, advice, and opinions. Do not cross-question the individual or give an impression of doubting the authenticity of their report. Protect privacy and assure confidentiality. Communicate in a manner that shows respect and dignity for their feelings.

Thank you for taking up the course.

Kindly close the window and take up the assessment to complete the module. The pass percentage is 80%
